biogHist.abstract:
Baltara Reception Centre was established by the Victorian Government in 1968 in the former 'Parkside' section of Turana, Parkville. It was a specialised reception facility for early adolescent boys, and from 1985 it was a youth training centre. In 1991-1992, Baltara's residents were moved into residential and reception units.
Before the 1980s there appeared to be a policy that when a child went from Baltara to a privately run Home (e.g. St Vincent's or St Augustine's), their Baltara file was transferred to the new agency.
biogHist.p: Baltara Reception Centre was established by the Victorian Government in 1968 in Parkville, as a separate entity from Turana which was on the same campus.
Baltara was situated in the former 'Parkside' section of Turana.
In the 1960s it was not uncommon for over 100 boys to be resident at Baltara due to the lack of suitable placements in children's Homes.
Baltara's separation from Turana was emphasised through the establishment of its own school and administration block in the early 1970s.

The Children and Young Persons Act 1989 legislated the need to separate children and young people on protective orders from youth offenders in custody. Turana, Winlaton and Baltara continued to operate in the short term, but only as youth training centres to provide appropriate programs for young people sentenced to detention.

In 1991/92, following the introduction of the Children and Young Persons Act, the old style congregate care campus at Baltara was closed. In its place, the Department developed small-scale geographically dispersed residential and reception units within the community.
In 1999, the former site of Baltara was redeveloped into the Parkville Youth Residential Centre.
